article: On Sunday morning, January 29, the call woke me up. It was the president of ABC News. "Lee, Bob has been  _  in Iraq," he said, choosing his words  _  . "He's alive but he may have taken shrapnel to the brain." When I saw Bob in the hospital, nothing could have  _  me. He was unconscious. His  _  was swollen to the size of a rugby ball and a piece of his skull was missing. All sorts of  _  were coming out of his body. His left eye looked like a dead fish. I tried to  _  myself that he didn't look that bad, that this was the  _  and that he'd only get better from here. There were many months of treatment  _  . Every morning I would head over to the hospital and check on Bob. In the  _  that a mother uses with her baby I would  _  to him. I let him know about the kids. I told him stories about us and some of our best  _  together. I brought music and had home movies for Bob to hear. One day when I pushed open the door as usual, I  _  . Bob was sitting up in bed, a huge smile on his face. He saw me and  _  his hands in the air. "Hey, sweetie," he said, "where have you been?" I tried to speak but no words came out. This was so much more than I'd wanted and prayed for,  _  I couldn't really believe it. My husband was  _  and he was calling me. Half of me wanted to shout in  _  and gratitude and half of me wanted to  _  everything, how I'd been there day after day for months. I  _  to him. Bob was  _  . He had the best medical treatment possible and the finest doctors. But the most important thing  turned out  to be the love that held us close.
